description:
Game description by the publisher:
"A game by ASSASSIN, in co-production with Lutz Leischner. 
A nice boardgame with tin miniatures, which should not be taken too seriously. We just call it Monstern!"

The game includes several nice tin miniatures, a gameboard and several dice.

Take it to the Limit is an advanced version of Take it Easy!.  Compared to the original game the boards are bigger in terms of the number of hexagonal spaces. There are 64 tiles in each set, with four different colors running in each direction. These tiles are subdivided evenly into ‘moon’ tiles and ‘sun’ tiles. There are also a number of Gold and Silver bonus tiles. If you complete scoring rows in all three directions through these tiles, then you can also add the bonus values to your total!

The individual playing boards are double-sided, so you can choose to play on the challenging ‘Nexus’ board (45 minutes), or on the stylish Orchid board for a quicker and distinctly different game (25 minutes).

When playing on the Nexus board, all 64 tiles are used. You can enhance your score by skillful use of the Gold and Silver bonus tiles and by cunningly interlacing ‘sunrays’ and ‘moonbeams’ with your other scoring rows. If it all seems to be going desperately wrong, you can dispose of unwanted tiles by placing them in your ‘Scrap Yard’. But beware - an ‘untidy’ scrapyard can cost you penalty points!

When playing on the Orchid board, choose either the ‘sun’ or ‘moon’ tiles. The special orchid symbols allow you to set aside unwanted tiles, with an option to increase your score by relocating them at the end of the game.

Content:
27 picture cards, 4 value stones, 1 pawn, 1 dog, board

In this game a young boy walks around the strand and looks to see what he can discover there. When he meets his girlfriend he has to tell what he has seen.
The winner is the player who first reaches the field with the sun with his value stone.

Each turn players get tiles with pictures of common beach objects, and each turn they try to remember, in order, the previous tiles they have seen.  Remembering correctly earns you points, and the first to 11 points wins.

from Winsome Games:

"Wooden Shoes & Iron Monsters" is a Riding Series game by Han Heidema. WS&IM is set in the Netherlands and covers to history of the Dutch railroads from 1830 to 2006. WS&IM is for 3-5 players for about 2-3 hours. Players start railroads, capitalize them with shares of stock, build track from city to city, receive income and later merge smaller railroads into larger railroads. Prior games in this series include West Riding, LÃ¤nderbahnen and Riding through England.

Main issue game contained in Alea Magazine issue 31.

Kursk 1943: The Northern Pincer, the End of Blitzkrieg (Part I) is a regiment-brigade simulation of the offensive of the 9th German Army during the battle of Kursk.

Colorful Caterpillars is a fun children's tactics game. The game is to get all of their own larvae first on to the game board. Players place their larvae on to the game board in turns. A great maneuvering game, where the larvae can be put this way, that someone else need to take theirs off or can't put their on to the board. Age range of more than 4 years.
Each player gets larvae pictured tiles, where in every single one of those is two holes, but they are in different places. One in head and tail of the larvae, or body and tail and so on. The tiles are in four different colors for each player. The game board have different colored circles on it, and your goal is to make your larvae complete by placing them in a way the circle match the color underneath (yellow to yellow). Win by getting rid of your tiles first.

Mestarietsivä Basil Hiiri (Fin.) / Mästerdetektiven Basil Mus (Swe.) (English: "The Master-Detective Basil Mouse") is a board game based on the Walt Disney movie Basil the Great Mouse Detective. Players follow the footsteps of the great mouse detective through the streets of London as he chases Professor Ratigan and his gang.

In the game players use numbered cards to travel from one corner of the board to another via roads and rotating crossroads. Crossroads can be used to hinder other players. The goal of the game is to get into Big Ben (Clock Tower / now: Elizabeth Tower) when the clock hits twelve o'clock.

Trinity is a New Zealand designed and published abstract strategy game for 2 players.  The game is played on a 4 by 4 square grid, which is marked a-d on the horizontal axis and 1-4 on the vertical axis for record keeping.

There are three types of pieces, which are identical for black and white.  First are the ORBS, which are circular pieces with red, yellow, green or blue in the center. The second type of pieces are ARCS, which have a stripe of color matching those of the orbs.  The arcs are 120 degrees in extension, so three arcs fit around an orb.  HALOS are the third piece type, and are either white or black.  They are rings which fit outside the orbs and arcs.  There are four orbs, four arcs and six halos of each color, made of plastic.

The orbs are set up on the 1 and 4 rows with the matching color arcs with those orbs.  Play consists of each player moving one orb one square horizontally, vertically or diagonally.  The matching color of arc MUST be then moved.  Arcs can move to any other legal square on the board.

The easiest way to win is to trap an opposing orb with three arcs of any color around it (an Arc-win).  If you can box in your opponents orbs so that he has no valid moves, then you have gained an Orb-win.  Finally, if you can move your four pieces inside four halos of your own color you have completed a halo win.  A draw is an option through player agreement or stalemate from repeated moves.

A halo is "earned" by moving three of your arcs so that they form a complete ring, with no orbs inside it.  The arcs then attack the opposing pieces of the same strip color as the arcs.

The game rules come in a 16-page A6 sized rule book. There is also a CD for Windows PCs to practice strategies.

From the box top: "All you need to host your own evening with Dracula - from atmospheric audio tape to blood capsules and fangs. The spookiest party game."

From the underside: "You are stranded in a house as a result of a storm and one of the people present is COUNT DRACULA. The object of the game is for the players to discover the identity of Dracula. Players are gathered in one part of the house and their fate and actions are decided by the spinner. As players move about the darkened house they are likely to meet Dracula or one of his vampires and be turned into VAMPIRES themselves. The mood in the house is set by the cassette tape, with the sound of eerie music, doors slamming, wind howling, thunder crashing, along with the VOICE OF DOOM, and the TOLL OF BELLS! You and your friends are guaranteed an evening of laughter, fun and scares. No Game ever plays the same. The more often the game is played the more fun everyone will have as they become skilled in the art of detecting and avoiding Dracula."

The players are travellers which are stuck in a small tavern in the woods during a storm. One of them is Count Dracula, the evil vampire. The players try to discover Dracula's identity. 
All players gather around the "wheel of fortune" and explore the playing area from here. They do this trying to flee from the count and his vampire henchmen. If a player is caught, he too turns into a vampire.

Components:
1 Audio cassette
1 Wheel of Fortune
12 Plastic Vampire Fangs
12 Letters of invitation
12 Small coffins
102 Playing cards (denominations of German edition):
  36 Mission
  18 Unheil
  12 Kreuz
  12 Knoblauch
  11 Vampir
  1 Pflock
  12 Gastkarten

1 Rule book
1 Tips for the host

Which snail will win the exciting race, roll the right colors on their dice and reach the goal first? Watch out: Not only speed counts! If you run too fast you can easily stumble and get a knot on you snail's tail... and that costs time! Therefore remember, dear snail, that more haste makes less speed, and be careful so that you reach your goal safely.

Or, as they would say in Germany:

Welche Schnecke wird wohl das spannende Rennen gewinnen, die richtige Farbe würfeln und als erste ans Ziel gelangen? Doch aufgepasst: Nich nur die Geschwindigkeit zählt! Denn wer zu schnell läuft, kann leicht stolpern und einen Knoten in seinen Schneckenschwanz bekommen... und das kostet Zeit! Darum, liebe Schnecke, eile mit Weile und Bedacht, damit du heil am Ziel ankommst.

This game is the graduation work of a student of visual communication in Weimar.
In the game players assume the roles of illegal immigrants trying to acquire a German passport while living from illegal work and evading the police.

Home Page: http://www.keinpasskeinspass.de/

It's a set of ninety cards in two categories: questions and answers.  From the box, it's a "merry question and answer card game for merry parties".

The questions begin with "What would you do if...".  The answers are along the lines of "I would soak it in milk".
This game simulates a soccer match. Two players roll dice, moves your teams and try to mark the biggest number of goals.

The Casey Jones Game Box contains three games: Blow the Whistle, Capital Run, and Freight Train.  All games are played with a single die, and (at most) 20 train cars.  Blow the Whistle is a simple race game for two players, playable by children as young as three-years-old. Players roll and move, with the requirement that they make horn sounds at certain points in the game.  The first player to reach the finish line wins.  Capital Run is a game for older children, with up to four players.  This game also has a roll-and-move mechanic, and players must successfully name state capitals in order to earn a turn, with the object to cross the country on a preset path.  Freight train is light but nontrivial game for two players, requiring players to assemble a set of different types of trains.  These trains (coal tender, box car, flat car, cattle car) begin the game on preset spaces, and players must roll around the board and assemble their set.  There are several opportunities for decisions.

Walt Disney's Davy Crockett Adventures, basically each player tries to collect all four Davy Crockett adventure cards onto his playing rack. 
These consist of: 'Davy Grins the Bear' , 'Davy Fights Redstick' ,'Davy Goes to Congress' , and 'Davy at the Alamo'
This collection process involves the spinning of a spinner (which is a picture of Fess Parker as Davy Crockett holding a rifle) when the rifle points to one of the adventure cards it is yours. The only catch is that you have to collect the adventures in the order that they happened.

Object: Four different Popeye Adventures are illustrated on the board. The object of play is for the player to win each of the four adventures by "eating" enough cans of spinach (wooden green discs), which are won in the "Grand Spinach Lottery". After winning an adventure the player receives an Adventure Card. The first player to win all four Adventure Cards and get to the finish is the winner of the game. The game has a typical spinner, cards, wooden "cans of spinach", and a "Grand Spinach Lottery" which is a box that you shake tokens out of, the tokens state how many cans of spinach you will receive.

The Object is to be the first player to cross the street on the blue border "GIANT STEPS" and then back again to his colored "Start" space.
 Draw cards, do what they say in order to move. The game requires good manners to move, you must say "May I" of the person on the right, if you don't you lose your turn.

Object: To become the first player to reach freedom in Canada, by answering trivia questions and avoiding the "Patroller" pawn who gets closer for each incorrect answer. Dice are used for only the first turn, after that movement is decided by the trivia cards. The papers inside the box state that there were only 1000 of this game produced.

A trivia game on antiques and collectibles.  Questions are given in three levels of difficulty: browser, buff, and advanced collector.  Each player chooses a level at the beginning of the game, thus allowing experts to play with beginners.  Each card has a relatively easy question (1 point if correct) and a relatively difficult question (2 points if correct).  Players announce their intention to answer the easy or difficult question before the next card is revealed.  First player to 30 points wins the game.

"The Child Making Game: Do you believe in the stork?"

From the back of the box:

The Child Making Game, intended for the 7th to 9th graders(* of the elementary school, is a fun teaching tool for the health and reproductive biology classes. The game has also been used a lot in youth work.

The game can lessen prejudices about pregnancy and add positive knowledge about pregnancy, childbirth and relationships. The effects of smoking, alcohol and unhealthy habits to the foetus and the expecting mother are informed about precisely and in a matter-of-fact manner.

The Child Making Game has been in use in schools for more than a decade, and has gained plenty of positive feedback from both teachers and pupils.

---


    ) 13-16 year olds.

Dice assigns a color tile, tile color placed on board with matching color but more points awarded for longest pattern (line of the same colors--a "Coloraddo") created from reverse of tile.  When tiles are all on the board, the game is over and the winner is the one with the highest score.

Players answer questions about the Malcolm in the Middle television show while collecting money for right answers.  Wrong answers have the money going to a jackpot.  The first player to collect $100 wins.

Players must collect a complete set of 6 male or female sex organ cards.  To win with the male organs, he/she must collect 500 million sperm and then land on the motel. To win with the female organs, he/she must also have one unfertilized egg and land on the bedroom.

The male sex organs are:

Snake of Life
Jewel Plum of Naughty Desires
Valve of Relief
Horn of Plenty
Boulevard of Urgency
Sack of Containment

The female sex organs are:

Gates of Forbidden Pleasures
Avenue of Rapture
Digit of Delight
Tube of Sanctuary
Basket of Hidden Danger
Hall of Conception

18TN is Mark Derrick's game set in Tennessee and Kentucky, similar to his 18AL and 18GA.  This game is what 1851 was based on, but the substantial changes introduced by Chris Lawson make it play quite differently.

18TN is simple enough to use for teaching the 18xx game system to new players, and finishes in a reasonable time as well.

Patrol Torpedo

Patrol Torpedo is a game representing tactical naval combat between coastal forces during World War II.  The player assumes the role of motor torpedo or gun boat skippers and their opponents, up to and including destroyers and other small escort craft.

Game Scale and Conventions


The game is designed to be played using miniature figures and terrain.  The game is generally played using figures in the scale of 1/300 or 1/600 scale.1 turn - 50 Seconds
1 cm   - 25 Meters
1 Knot - 1 cm of movement

From the back of the box:

Rock to the top!  It's a race to stardom at the biggest rock concert of the year!  Take a spin to create a stylin' wardrobe!  Gather rockin' music and stock up on lots of bling!  The right combination will land you onstage, where you win the game- and you rock the spotlight!

Who will be the first to catch the fly in the middle?

Spiderrinth is a fun and tactical game, where the objective is to be the first to make a trail from one's home field inwards to the fly in the center of the web.

The trail is established by turning the treads and putting chips on the flies. When all the flies from one's home field to the center of the web is covered by a chip, you move your piece onto the prey in the center and thereby win the game - but only if you remember to say "Spiderrinth"!

(From the box - translated from Danish)

A player moves ahead on the board with a piece by rolling the die or pair of dice.  The landing space has a color.  A card of the same color is drawn.  If the player can correctly answer the question, the player can throw the dice and move ahead again.  Also, the player is given a puzzle piece matching the color/category if the player does not already have that piece.  The first player to complete a flag (using the puzzle pieces), return to California and answer a final question, wins.
An exciting game for all ages about Savannah!  Also includes $100 worth of coupons for local businesses!

This is a children's game with a 3-D board (when the cardboard is properly assembled).  The most prominent part of the board is the large slide along one side of the board.

From the box: 
"Side Splitting Hi-Jinks with The 3 STOOGES in a Real Zany Fun House!"

Pisa is a strategy and fine motor skills game. Roll the dice to see how many pieces must be used. Start by building one level and move up to building four. Try to avoid a leaning tower as you carefully place bamboo pieces to support more levels.

Age: 4+

Maselino is a game of speed. 40 Colorful bamboo discs are distributed by color to players who pretend they are mice looking for food. The players turn the tiles over until their pictures match. When they do, the players rob the piece of food from the plates in the middle. Only the quickest one can keep it. The winner is the one who gets the most pieces of food.

Age: 4+

Battelo is a memory and strategy game. Players move their panda bear through the forest according to the memo tiles they draw and try to be the first to collect 4 different colored leaves in their backpacks.

Age: 4+

"Godfathers & Goodfellas" is a trivia board game that is driven by the popularity of the "wiseguy" genre, particularly in movies and on TV series such as “The Sopranos.” The game consists of a series of categories relevant to the 'mob scene' with questions in each category. The player is a good guy -- a special agent assigned to break up the mob by answering questions. With every correct answer, down goes another bad guy. The harder the question the bigger the bad guy … until the whole gang is gone.

Avesta! is an abstract game themed loosely on the Zend Avesta - the sacred texts of Zoroaster (also called Zarathustra). It is chess-like in the powers and types of moves available, but there are a few spaces on the board that are limited to certain pieces, some pieces are used for blocking only, and some pieces are promoted when others are captured, which can tip the balance, making a capture or sacrifice critical to the outcome. There are two winning conditions: either the capture of the opponent’s offensive pieces, or the defilement (occupation) of your opponent’s temple for a full turn.

From the advertisement:

Gift of Enlightenment is a unique and totally original board game that brings a flow of positive energy to all who discover it. Friends and family will be delighted by its healing messages and fun game play. This is one adventure that is guaranteed to stay in the mind long after the final dice has been thrown.

Game Features: - Seek your very own ‘Gift of Enlightenment’. Make life-changing decisions as you travel the ‘Circle of Life’.  Win and lose positive and negative human traits along the way.  Harness the energy around you. It can help you to reach the ultimate goal.  How powerful are your Sixth Sense, Insight, and Intuition?  Here’s your chance to find out as you seek to master the ‘Seven Chakra Challenges’.  Collect the Seven Chakra Crystals that can help you to open the wonderful ‘Book of Enlightenment’.

Delve into the mysterious Karma Pool.  Try to avoid falling for False Idols.  Gain a personal gift from the ‘Book of Enlightenment’.

Each beautifully boxed game contains: -

Game board

7 special Chakra stones with velvet holding bag.

6 Aura cards

3 packs of game cards

42 Chakra crystals (acrylic)

7 Chakra color cards

7 Chakra Challenges.

Wooden Dice

Full Instructions

Plus the 82 page ‘Book of Enlightenment’

Steward

In STEWARD, your mission is to manage and multiply the riches that have been entrusted to you.

Great riches are in your hands • What will you do with them

Make different purchase in order to produce olive oil, clay pots, food grains, clothes and more. Buy and export stone to build houses or temples or become the biggest copper producer in your area.  Discover the Biblical Principles that will make you a Great Steward! Never forget to tithe on all your income. It will be the key to your prosperity. Use strategy to succeed in the challenge that has been entrusted to you and by doing so become THE BEST STEWARD.

STEWARD • A captivating game that you will certainly enjoy and that will be the source of many unforgettable moments with your family and your friends.

Parts of Speech Challenge reinforces knowledge of nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, prepositions, pronouns, conjunctions and interjections! 
 Parts of Speech Challenge helps players master the eight basic parts of speech plus verb phrases, prepositional phrases, articles, and proper nouns. Players learn how the same word can represent different parts of speech based on how it is used in a sentence.
 As they move around the board, drawing cards and reading sentences, players identify the parts of speech of selected words. All words are used in sentence context for meaningful learning.
 The Reference Sheet, included, allows players to familiarize themselves with the parts of speech. Younger players can use the Reference Sheet while playing the game.
 The object is to cover the most spaces on the board before one player runs out of markers. The player with the highest score wins!

A simple and fun dice game for young children!  Players roll five dice with animal pictures (lion, monkey, giraffe, crocodile, elephant and hippo) on each side, and try to collect sets of matching animals.  The "Lion" picture is "wild".  After the first roll, players are allowed to re-roll the dice of their choice up to two times.  Players then place the equivalent number of matching animal tokens on their playing board.  This process is repeated for each player five times.  The winner is the player with the most monkey, giraffe, crocodile, elephant and hippo tokens on their playing board!  Suitable for children age 4 and older.

Contents:

     4 play boards 
     100 chips 
     5 dice 
     1 dice cup 
     1 sticker sheet 
     instructions

In Mithril, each player plays a team of dwarves exploring a mine to discover buried valuables, such as gold, beer, mithril and a treasure chest. Players must dig carefully to avoid being crushed in a cave-in, as the mines' stability is unpredictable, and the other players can sometimes trigger cave-ins and other hazards.

The game ends when a players brings the treasure chest back to his entrance. Then, the richest player wins the game.

The game is still under development.

Players must think of solutions to the stressful situations that they meet in the game and then discuss the results.  Everyone wins in Stress Strategies by listening, sharing, and accepting the feelings and responses of all the players, and by learning healthy ways to manage stress.

Based on the popular book by Michael Ende. One player takes the role of Jim Knopf, who wants to take as many friends as possible with him in Lukas' - who is played by another player - locomotive Emma. But even in Lummerland - the imaginary island, where the train tracks lead around - you need a ticket to ride the train. And it isn't as easy to get one of those...

Zzzymble is a card game inspired by Sudoku and is a fast paced card game that is fun for all ages.

The box contains cards with five suits, containing the numbers 1-9, plus various special cards that affect gameplay. Players are trying to play their cards into a 5x5 grid. Cards may not be played adjacently (orthogonally or diagonally) to another card that match either number or color. When the grid is full, players sum card values remaining in their hands. Over a number of rounds (playing to 100 points), the winner is the player with the fewest points.

A planned forthcoming expansion is called "It's as Zzzymble as Zzzat."

Help Pip & Pop, Tutter and Ojo find their favorite things hidden in Bear's yard.  Spin to move ahead.  Land on special spaces and turn over Bush tokens to see what's hidden where.  Find two of your character's favorite things and reach Bear's house first to win.

Each player spins to establish their color.  The 24 puzzle pieces are evenly distributed.  The red player starts by trying to put the puzzle together while the person on their left is trying to spin red's color.  When red is spun, the player spinning tries to put the puzzle together while the person on their left tries to spin that persons color.  The first player to use all of their puzzle pieces is the winner.
Crazy 8ths is a music based educational card game that introduces many variants to popular card games, and is designed to help children learn to read music.

Another Monopoly variant.  Utilities are replaced by observatories, railroads by telescope manufacturers and properties by celestial bodies.  The pewter pieces are: radio telescope, telescope in dome, Hubble Space Telescope, Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope, binoculars and lawn chair.

Quoted from the game box: “BOK is a fast paced strategy game that is more demanding and challenging than Backgammon or Chess. Truly a remarkable and intriguing concept, unparalleled in the history of games.  BOK will remain unchallenged in years to come as The Ultimate Strategy Game.”

Salut Les Filles! must be played within a public area, such as a pub or coffee.

Players play cards describing a physical element that can be found on a person, such as long hair, cell phone, she kisses me, etc...

The first player to spot a person with at least one attribute on a card gets the card and marks a point, other players have to agree if the person corresponds with the card's element.

Each player takes a net and on the count of three, presses four grasshoppers down on the board as fast as they can. In a few seconds, the suction cups will loosen and the grasshoppers will hop high into the air. The player who catches the most in his or her net wins.

Players compete in a test of knowledge, trying to win the most money by answering questions in the category of their choice.

Based on the TV game show of the same name, hosted by Mike Darrow (pictured on box) for its first season (1976-77).
